member.summary: Plays the specified .
member.param: The to play.
A value indicating whether to loop the song.
member.returns: true if the song began playing successfully; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Audio.SongPlayer.Play(TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Audio.Song,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Plays the specified .
member.param: The to play.
A value from 0.0 (silent) to 1.0 (full volume) representing the song's volume.
A value from -1.0 (down one octave) to 1.0 (up one octave) indicating the song's pitch adjustment.
A value from -1.0 (full left) to 1.0 (full right) representing the song's panning position.
A value indicating whether to loop the song.
member.returns: true if the song began playing successfully; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Stops the song that is currently playing.

member.summary: Pauses the song that is currently playing.

member.summary: Resumes the song after it has been paused.

member.summary: Gets the duration of the currently-playing song.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value from 0.0 (silent) to 1.0 (full volume) representing the volume of the currently-playing song.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value from -1.0 (down one octave) to 1.0 (up one octave) indicating the pitch adjustment of the currently-playing song.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value from -1.0 (full left) to 1.0 (full right) representing the panning position of the currently-playing song.

member.name: M:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Color.TryParseHex(System.String,System.Globalization.NumberStyles,System.IFormatProvider,TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Color@)
member.summary: Converts the string representation of a color into an instance of the structure. A return value indicates whether the conversion succeeded.
member.param: A string containing a color to convert.
A set of values indicating which elements are present in .
A format provider that provides culture-specific formatting information.
A variable to populate with the converted value.
member.returns: true if was converted successfully; otherwise, false.
member.remarks:
Strings parsed by this method must be in one of the following formats:
#rgb
#argb
#rrggbb
#aarrggbb

member.name: M:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Color.TryParseDelimitedOrNamed(System.String,System.Globalization.NumberStyles,System.IFormatProvider,TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Color@)
member.summary: Converts the string representation of a color into an instance of the structure. A return value indicates whether the conversion succeeded.
member.param: A string containing a color to convert.
A set of values indicating which elements are present in .
A format provider that provides culture-specific formatting information.
A variable to populate with the converted value.
member.returns: true if was converted successfully; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: Strings parsed by this methods must be comma-delimited lists of three or four color components, in either R, G, B or A, R, G, B format, or a named color.

member.name: P:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Content.ContentManager.RootDirectory
member.summary: Gets the content manager's root directory.

member.name: P:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Content.ContentManager.OverrideDirectories
member.summary: Gets the content manager's collection of override directories.
member.remarks: Override directories are alternative paths where the content manager will search for asset files. If multiple override directories contain an asset with the same path, directories which have higher indices within this collection will take priority over directories with lower indices, "overriding" the other values of the asset in question. All override directories take precedence over the content manager's root directory.

member.name: P:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Content.ContentManager.BatchDeletedFiles
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the content manager should batch file deletions.
member.remarks: When this property is set to true, will not delete files immediately. Instead, it will buffer deletions until the batch is ended. This is useful when, for example, preprocessing a large number of files which depend on the same raw resources; batching deletes ensures that those raw resources remain on disk until all of the assets are preprocessed.

member.summary: Represents the ways in which a sprite batch can sort its sprites.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.Graphics2D.SpriteSortMode.Deferred
member.summary: Sprites are not drawn until the batch ends, and then are drawn in the order that they were added to the batch.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.Graphics2D.SpriteSortMode.Immediate
member.summary: Sprites are rendered immediately, without any batching.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.Graphics2D.SpriteSortMode.Texture
member.summary: Sprites are sorted according to their texture.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.Graphics2D.SpriteSortMode.BackToFront
member.summary: Sprites are sorted according to their layer depth, from back to front.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.Graphics2D.SpriteSortMode.FrontToBack
member.summary: Sprites are sorted according to the layer depth, from front to back.

member.name: M:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.Graphics2D.Text.TextRenderer.GetLineAtPosition(TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.Graphics2D.Text.TextLayoutCommandStream,TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Vector2,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets the index of the line of text at the specified layout-relative position.
member.param: The command stream that contains the layout information to evaluate.
The position to evaluate.
If true, a line is considered to fill the entire horizontal extent of the layout area, regardless of the line's actual width.
member.returns: The index of the line of text at the specified layout-relative position, or null if the specified position is not contained by any line.

member.summary: Gets the index of the insertion point which is closest to the specified layout-relative position.
member.remarks: An insertion point represents a position at which new text can be inserted into the formatted text, starting at index 0 (before the first character) and ending at , inclusive (after the last character).
member.param: The command stream that contains the layout information to evaluate.
The position to evaluate.
member.returns: The index of the insertion point which is closest to the specified layout-relative position.

member.name: T:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: The namespace contains types relating to Ultraviolet's graphics subsystem.

member.name: T:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.PrimitiveType
member.summary: Represents the supported primitive types, which specify how vertex data is ordered within a buffer.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.PrimitiveType.TriangleList
member.summary: The vertex data is ordered as a sequence of triangles, with each triangle described by three new vertices.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.PrimitiveType.TriangleStrip
member.summary: The vertex data is ordered as a sequence of triangles, with each triangle described by three new vertices and one vertex from the previous triangle.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.PrimitiveType.LineList
member.summary: The vertex data is ordered as a sequence of line segments, with each line segment described by two new vertices.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.PrimitiveType.LineStrip
member.summary: The vertex data is ordered as a sequence of line segments, with each line segment described by one new vertex and one vertex from the previous line segment.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.RenderTargetUsage.PlatformContents
member.summary: The render target's data is preserved on platforms which support doing so in hardware, and discarded on platforms which do not provide such support.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.RenderTargetUsage.PreserveContents
member.summary: The render target's data is always preserved when the render target is bound. Some platforms may not support this in hardware, leading to performance issues; check the value of to determine whether this is the case.

member.summary: Represents the origin of texture data which is being set onto a texture or render buffer. If the data source's origin differs from the texture's expected origin, the buffer may be re-arranged during the copy in order to match what the texture expects.

member.summary: The buffer being copied contains data with a top-left origin.

member.name: T:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.StencilOperation
member.summary: Represents the stencil buffer operations.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.StencilOperation.Decrement
member.summary: Decrements the stencil buffer value, wrapping to the maximum value if the new value is less than 0.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.StencilOperation.DecrementSaturation
member.summary: Decrements the stencil buffer value, clamping to 0.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.StencilOperation.Increment
member.summary: Increments the stencil buffer value, wrapping to the minimum value if the new value exceeds the maximum value.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.StencilOperation.IncrementSaturation
member.summary: Increments the stencil buffer value, clamping to the maximum value.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.StencilOperation.Invert
member.summary: Inverts the bits of the stencil buffer value.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.StencilOperation.Keep
member.summary: Preserves the stencil buffer value.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.StencilOperation.Replace
member.summary: Replaces the stencil buffer value with the reference value.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Graphics.StencilOperation.Zero
member.summary: Sets the stencil buffer value to zero.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.International1
member.summary: The first international key.
member.remarks: From http://www.quadibloc.com/comp/scan.htm: INT 1 is the key next to the left shift key on an international keyboard. On many international keyboards, it has the characters < and >, but on the United Kingdom keyboard, it has | and \.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.International2
member.summary: The second international key.
member.remarks: From http://www.quadibloc.com/comp/scan.htm: INT 2 is the lower key of the two to the right of the Enter key on an international keyboard. Confusingly, it, and not the one with | and \ on it in the UK, has the same scan code in some sets as the U. S. | and \ key; and on the Canadian French keyboard, it is this key that has < and > on it. In the United Kingdom, the characters on this key are ~ and #.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.International3
member.summary: The third international key.
member.remarks: From http://www.quadibloc.com/comp/scan.htm: INT 3 is found both on some Brazilian keyboards and on the Japanese keyboard used for a Kanji input method (it has hiragana on the keys, as opposed to the other form of a plain Japanese keyboard with katakana on the keys). On the Japanese keyboard, it has _ and \ on it, and is located next to the right shift key.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.International4
member.summary: The fourth international key.
member.remarks: From http://www.quadibloc.com/comp/scan.htm: INT 4 is also found on the Japanese keyboard. It has | and on it and is located next to the backspace key.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.International5
member.summary: The fifth international key.
member.remarks: From http://www.quadibloc.com/comp/scan.htm: INT 5 is located on the numeric keypad on some Brazilian keyboards. It has the same Group 3 scan code as the extra key on the numeric keypad of 122-key keyboards when the code assignments used for keyboards used with IBM terminals are followed.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.International6
member.summary: The sixth international key.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.International7
member.summary: The seventh international key.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.International8
member.summary: The eighth international key.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.International9
member.summary: The ninth international key.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.Lang1
member.summary: The first language key.
member.remarks: From http://www.usb.org/developers/devclass_docs/Hut1_12v2.pdf: Hangul/English toggle key. This usage is used as an input method editor control key on a Korean language keyboard.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.Lang2
member.summary: The second language key.
member.remarks: From http://www.usb.org/developers/devclass_docs/Hut1_12v2.pdf: Hanja conversion key. This usage is used as an input method editor control key on a Korean language keyboard.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.Lang3
member.summary: The third language key.
member.remarks: From http://www.usb.org/developers/devclass_docs/Hut1_12v2.pdf: Defines the Katakana key for Japanese USB word-processing keyboards.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.Lang4
member.summary: The fourth language key.
member.remarks: From http://www.usb.org/developers/devclass_docs/Hut1_12v2.pdf: Defines the Hiragana key for Japanese USB word-processing keyboards.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.Lang5
member.summary: The fifth language key.
member.remarks: From http://www.usb.org/developers/devclass_docs/Hut1_12v2.pdf: Defines the Zenkaku/Hankaku key for Japanese USB word-processing keyboards.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.Lang6
member.summary: The sixth language key.
member.remarks: From http://www.usb.org/developers/devclass_docs/Hut1_12v2.pdf: Reserved for language-specific functions, such as Front End Processors and Input Method Editors.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.Lang7
member.summary: The seventh language key.
member.remarks: From http://www.usb.org/developers/devclass_docs/Hut1_12v2.pdf: Reserved for language-specific functions, such as Front End Processors and Input Method Editors.

member.name: F:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.Scancode.Lang8
member.summary: The eighth language key.
member.remarks: From http://www.usb.org/developers/devclass_docs/Hut1_12v2.pdf: Reserved for language-specific functions, such as Front End Processors and Input Method Editors.

member.summary: The ninth language key.

member.name: T:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.TouchTapEventHandler
member.summary: Represents the method that is called when a finger is tapped against a touch device.
member.param: The that raised the event.
A value which identifies the finger which was tapped.
The x-coordinate at which the tap began.
The y-coordinate at which the tap began.

member.name: T:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.TouchFingerEventHandler
member.summary: Represents the method that is called when a finger is pressed against or removed from a touch device.
member.param: The that raised the event.
A value which identifies the finger which was pressed or removed.
The normalized x-coordinate at which the finger was pressed or removed.
The normalized y-coordinate at which the finger was pressed or removed.
The normalized pressure with which the touch was applied.

member.name: T:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.TouchFingerMotionEventHandler
member.summary: Represents the method that is called when a finger is moved across a touch device.
member.param: The that raised the event.
A value which identifies the finger which was moved.
The finger's normalized x-coordinate on the touch device.
The finger's normalized y-coordinate on the touch device.
The change in the finger's x-coordinate.
The change in the finger's y-coordinate.
The normalized pressure of the finger against the device.

member.name: T:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.MultiTouchEventHandler
member.summary: Represents the method that is called when a multitouch gesture is performed.
member.param: The that raised the event.
The x-coordinate of the normalized center of the gesture.
The y-coordinate of the normalized center of the gesture.
The amount that the fingers rotated during the gesture.
The amount that the fingers pinched during the gesture.
The number of fingers that were used in the gesture.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Updates the device's state.
member.param: Time elapsed since the last call to .

member.name: M:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.TouchDevice.WasTapped
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the device was tapped anywhere on its surface during the previous frame.
member.returns: true if the device was tapped; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.TouchDevice.WasTapped(TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.RectangleF)
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the device was tapped anywhere in the specified area on its surface during the previous frame.
member.param: A structure containing the area to evaluate, specified in normalized coordinates.
member.returns: true if the device was tapped; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.TouchDevice.MaximumTapDistance
member.summary: Gets the maximum distance that a finger can move between its up and down events in order for the input to be considered a "tap." This value is in normalized units; i.e. a value of 0.05 means that the finger can move across 5% of the device and still be considered a tap.

member.name: P:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.Input.TouchDevice.MaximumTapDelay
member.summary: Gets the maximum delay in milliseconds between a finger's up and down events in order for the input to be considered a "tap."

member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the Ultraviolet context is headless. A headless context will not create a default window upon initialization.

member.name: P:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.UltravioletConfiguration.EnableServiceMode
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether service mode is enabled.

remarks.para: In service mode, the graphics subsystem is never intialized and no windows are ever created. This is different from headless mode, where the context's primary window is invisible but still exists.

This mode is primarily useful in circumstances where an Ultraviolet-based application has to run in the context of a Windows service, for example on a build server. The Windows security model prevents services from accessing the graphics device, so we need to avoid doing so or else we'll run into errors.

member.name: P:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.UltravioletConfiguration.WindowIsVisible
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the Ultraviolet context's default window is visible at startup. If the context is headless, this setting has no effect.

member.name: P:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.UltravioletConfiguration.WindowIsResizable
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the Ultraviolet context's default window can be resized. If the context is headless, this setting has no effect.

member.name: P:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.UltravioletConfiguration.WindowIsBorderless
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the Ultraviolet context's default window is borderless. If the context is headless, this setting has no effect.

member.name: P:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.UltravioletConfiguration.InitialWindowPosition
member.summary: Gets or sets the intial size and position of the context's primary window.

member.name: M:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.UltravioletContext.UpdateSuspended
member.summary: Updates the game state while the application is suspended.
member.remarks: Certain platforms, such as phones and tablets, may suspend the application while it is in the background in order to save power. Ultraviolet will automatically cease calling and when this happens; however, some implementations may require that certain processing continues to take place even while the application is suspended. The method is provided for such a scenario.

member.name: M:TwistedLogik.Ultraviolet.UltravioletContext.SpawnTask(System.Action{System.Threading.CancellationToken})
member.summary: Spawns a new task.
member.remarks: Tasks spawned using this method will not be started until the next call to , and will prevent the Ultraviolet context from shutting down until they complete or are canceled. Do not attempt to on these tasks from the main Ultraviolet thread; doing so will introduce a deadlock.
member.param: The action to perform within the task.
member.returns: The that was spawned.

member.name: T:sspack.OutOfSpaceException
member.summary: Insufficient space left in packing area to contain a given object
member.remarks: An exception being sent to you from deep space. Erm, no, wait, it's an exception that occurs when a packing algorithm runs out of space and is unable to fit the object you tried to pack into the remaining packing area.

member.name: T:sspack.ArevaloRectanglePacker
member.summary: Rectangle packer using an algorithm by Javier Arevalo

remarks.para: Original code by Javier Arevalo (jare at iguanademos dot com). Rewritten to C# / .NET by Markus Ewald (cygon at nuclex dot org). The following comments were written by the original author when he published his algorithm.

You have a bunch of rectangular pieces. You need to arrange them in a rectangular surface so that they don't overlap, keeping the total area of the rectangle as small as possible. This is fairly common when arranging characters in a bitmapped font, lightmaps for a 3D engine, and I guess other situations as well.

The idea of this algorithm is that, as we add rectangles, we can pre-select "interesting" places where we can try to add the next rectangles. For optimal results, the rectangles should be added in order. I initially tried using area as a sorting criteria, but it didn't work well with very tall or very flat rectangles. I then tried using the longest dimension as a selector, and it worked much better. So much for intuition...

These "interesting" places are just to the right and just below the currently added rectangle. The first rectangle, obviously, goes at the top left, the next one would go either to the right or below this one, and so on. It is a weird way to do it, but it seems to work very nicely.

The way we search here is fairly brute-force, the fact being that for most offline purposes the performance seems more than adequate. I have generated a japanese font with around 8500 characters and all the time was spent generating the bitmaps.
Also, for all we care, we could grow the parent rectangle in a different way than power of two. It just happens that power of 2 is very convenient for graphics hardware textures.
I'd be interested in hearing of other approaches to this problem. Make sure to post them on http://www.flipcode.com

member.name: T:sspack.ArevaloRectanglePacker.AnchorRankComparer
member.summary: Compares the 'rank' of anchoring points
member.remarks: Anchoring points are potential locations for the placement of new rectangles. Each time a rectangle is inserted, an anchor point is generated on its upper right end and another one at its lower left end. The anchor points are kept in a list that is ordered by their closeness to the upper left corner of the packing area (their 'rank') so the packer favors positions that are closer to the upper left for new rectangles.

member.summary: Compares the rank of two anchors against each other

member.returns: The relation of the two anchor point's ranks to each other

member.name: T:sspack.RectanglePacker
member.summary: Base class for rectangle packing algorithms

remarks.para: By uniting all rectangle packers under this common base class, you can easily switch between different algorithms to find the most efficient or performant one for a given job.
An almost exhaustive list of packing algorithms can be found here: http://www.csc.liv.ac.uk/~epa/surveyhtml.html
